IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: REFER TO SCHEDULE O FOR DESCRIPTION OF GEORGIA LIONS LIGHTHOUSE MOST SIGNIFICANT ACTIVITIES.Since 2005, the Lighthouse has achieved remarkable growth: Vision services have grown dramatically. Last year we helped with 320 eye surgeries . The Lighthouse partners with growing network of nonprofit health centers to offer monthly eye clinics at 17 statewide locations. As a result, the number of Georgians receiving eye exams and eyeglasses has increased from 400 to 3,200 annually. The hearing program saw about 993 clients this past year. The Lighthouse launched a captial campaign for a new facility with a permanent eye clinic. The Lighthouse is fully focused on serving more people who are in need of vision and hearing services. The campaign will bring this brighter future into focus, enabling the Lighthouse to serve thousands more Georgians each year.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The Georgia Lions Lighthouse Foundation provides vision and hearing services through education, detection, prevention and treatment. Through collaborative partnerships we enable greater independence and increased quality of life for Georgians in financial need.
IRS990.Description: In 2009, the Georgia Lions Lighthouse Foundation provided 320 eye surgeries to uninsured Georgians who had no other recourse to save or regain sight. The Lighthouse facilitates corneal transplants, cataract and retinal surgeries, and surgeries to prepare eye sockets for prosthetic eyes. We also provide surgery for diabetes-related vision loss and keratoconus. Our partnerships with over 200 ophthalmologists, hospitals, and other medical providers enable us to provide eye surgeries for one-fifth the typical cost.

Activity2.Description: Georgia Lions Lighthouse clinics , in 2009, provided over 3,200 people vision services. Our mobile clinic transfers equipment and sample eyeglass frames to 17 partner, non-profit health clinics thoughout GA. Volunteer optometrists and ophthalmologists provide eye exams, and populations at risk for eye disease are educated in prevention of these conditions.

Activity3.Description: Georgia Lions Lighthouse, in 2009, provided 1,700 hearing aids to 933 clients. In addition, each client received four follow up visits. In 2009, we doubled the number of hearing aids provided, we expanded areas of hearing aid service, we strengthened are partnerships with hearing aid providers, and our community engagement and education has increased through various screenings.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Organization has adopted investment and spending policies for endowment assets that attempt to provide a predictable stream of funding to programs supported by its endowment while seeking to maintain the historic dollar value of the endowment assets. Endowment assets include those assets of donor-restricted funds that the organization must hold in perpetuity as well as board-designated funds. These funds are to be used to underwrite administrative expenses from the earnings generated by the permanent funds.
Special Event Expenses Reported on Form 990 page 1, Line 9b: -30259.
Special Event Expenses Reported on Form 990 page 1, Line 9b: 30259.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Identifier: Method for Determining Number of Contributors:
Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The number of contributors is the number of donors.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Our independent auditors present Form 990 to the Board of Directors for review, discussion, and vote for approval.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Employees and board members have an obligation to conduct business within guidelines that prohibit actual or potential conflicts of interest. This policy establishes only the framework within which the Lighthouse Foundation wishes its business to operate. The purpose of these guidelines is to provide general direction so that employees can seek further clarification on issues related to the subject of acceptable standards of operation. An actual or potential conflict of interest occurs when an employee is in a position to influence a decision that may result in a personal gain for the employee or for a relative as a result of the Lighthouse Foundations business dealings. For the purpose of this policy, a relative is any person who is related by blood or marriage, or whose relationship with the employee is similar to that of persons who are related by blood or marriage. No "presumption of guilt" is created by the mere existence of a relationship with outside firms. However, if an employee has any influence on transactions involving purchases, contracts, or leases, it is imperative that he or she discloses to an officer of the organization as soon as possible the existence of any actual or potential conflict of interest so that safeguards can be established to protect all parties. Personal gain may result not only in cases where an employee, board member, or relative has a significant ownership in a firm with which XYZ does business, but also when an employee, board member, or relative receives any kickback, bribe, substantial gift, or special consideration as a result of any transaction of business dealings involving XYZ. The materials, products, designs, plans, ideas, and data of XYZ are the property of XYZ, and should never be given to an outside firm or individual except through normal channels and with appropriate authorization. Any improper transfer of material or disclosure of information, even though it is not apparent that an employee has personally gained by such action, constitutes unacceptable conduct. Any employee who participates in such a practice shall be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including discharge. A. Nepotism a. Employee: This is covered in the Personnel section of this document. b. Board: Board members and their immediate family members will be excluded from consideration for employment by the organization. B. Executive Limitations: The Executive Director may allow no practices or circumstances that violate commonly accepted business and professional ethics, common business prudence, or the Lions Club Code of Ethics.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board reviewed with Finance Chair and Vice Chair and also conducted a regional compensation study.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All documents are available upon request. Form 990 will be published in the entity's annual report.
The procedures for auditor selection and review of audited financials have not changed from the prior year.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990 Part VIII Program Revenue and Sch D Reconciliation of Revenue
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: CONTRIBUTED SERVICES AND MATERIALS Professional services and materials recognized in the financial statements for Georgia Lions Lighthouse Foundation, Inc as contributed services and materials for the year ended June 30, 2010 are as follows: Sight surgery service revenue $ 1,856,292 Hearing revenue 640,900 Clinic glasses revenue 1,342,462 Other specialized service revenue 101,955 ------------ Total $ 3,941,609 This amount is not recognized as progarm revenue on the tax return and is a reconciling item on Sch D, Part XII, Line 2b.
